title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: S&P 500 Index Briefly Trades Above All-time Closing High On Trade, Earnings Optimism
text:
By Clive McKeef and Joy Wiltermuth

Intel shares up 7%, Amazon's shares down 1.7% after earnings

U.S. stocks extended gains Friday, with the benchmark S&P 500 index briefly trading above its all-time closing high of 3,025.86 on July 26, while the Dow was up more than 150 points following encouraging signs in corporate earnings and reports that the U.S. and China were close to finalizing some sections of a recently agreed trade deal (link).

How are major indexes faring?

The S&P 500 index was up 9.88 points, or 0.33% at 3,020, after briefly trading above a prior closing record of 3,025.86 set on July 26. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was around 137 points higher at 26,942, a gain of 0.5% and below its all-time closing high of 27,359.16, also set in July. The Nasdaq Composite Index was up 44 points or 0.5% at 8,230.

On Thursday (link), the Dow closed 28.42 points, or 0.11%, lower, at 26,805.53, with a decline in shares of Post-it maker 3M weighing on the index. The S&P 500 index , meanwhile, gained 5.77 points to 3,010.29, while the Nasdaq Composite Index added 66 points, or 0.81%, at 8,185.80.

What's driving the market?

U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Friday (link) they have made progress on the first phase of a potential U.S.-China trade detente, which helped lift the stock market higher Friday.

"The price action today is due to expectations of a trade deal with China that may in fact take the December 15 tariffs off the table -- a key Chinese demand," Alicia Levine, chief strategist, BNY Mellon Investment Management, told MarketWatch.

"Right now this is improving market sentiment, but if the December 15 tariffs remain, 2020 earnings estimates are at risk."

Corporate earnings results have been a catalysts for stocks this week, with earnings from bellwether Intel and Amazon.com in focus Friday.

Intel (INTC) shares rose after better-than-expected earnings and revenue (link)but Amazon (AMZN) disappointed investors with its third-quarter results (link) sending the stock down.

More than 38% of S&P 500 companies posted quarter earnings for the third quarter thus far, according to FactSet. Of those companies, 78% have beaten analyst expectations.

See: Intel stock shoots higher but one key number has analysts worried (link)

Kristina Hooper, chief global market strategist at Invesco, said that progress on trade, upbeat earnings and expectations of another Federal Reserve interest rate cut next week were all key drivers of the stock market rally.

"That makes a very powerful Trifecta," she told MarketWatch. "And the good news is that investors are not letting a few high-profile earnings misses dictate their assessment about the facts in general."

See: Amazon earnings miss is the price of growth, analysts say (link)

Investors were also keeping an eye on Europe after French President Emmanuel Macron blocked the EU's attempt to delay Brexit for three months (link), but the European Commission said work on this would "continue in the coming days".

While the U.S. and China have made progress in trade talks and come close to finalizing parts of a phase one deal, doubts remain that a substantive U.S. - China trade agreement can be finalized.Top U.S. and Chinese trade officials are discussing plans on Friday for China to buy more U.S. farm products, but in return, Beijing will request cancellation of some planned and existing U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports, people briefed on the talks told Reuters (link). (link)

In U.S. economic news, the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index fell to 95.5 in October, from 96.0. "The economy is still in a good place consumers feel for now," MUFG chief economist Chris Rupkey said. "The consumer is more than willing to go it alone if necessary when it comes to the heavy lifting of the economy that is required for growth as business investment spending weakens due to the uncertainty caused by trade war tensions."

The U.S. government ran a budget deficit of just under $1 trillion (link)-- $984 billion -- in the fiscal year that ended in September. It was the largest shortfall since 2012, and was 26% more than the fiscal 2018 deficit of $779 billion. As a percentage of gross domestic product, the deficit was 4.6%, up from 3.8% in fiscal 2018.

Which stocks are in focus?

Intel Corp. (INTC) shares rose 7% after the chip maker raised its outlook for the year (link)on Thursday evening after it posted an increase in third-quarter earnings.

Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) dropped less than 2% on Friday after the tech giant reported a 26% fall in profit (link) late Thursday as it invested heavily to speed up shipping times.

Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ) stock fell despite an earlier gain after an earnings beat (link). (link) The telecommunications giant added new phone subscribers and net income attributable to Verizon was $5.19 billion, up from $4.92 billion a year earlier. Quarterly revenue edged up slightly to $32.9 billion from $32.6 billion a year ago.

Boeing Co.'s (BA) 737 MAX was blamed formally in the Lion Air fatal nose dive (link)into the Java Sea nearly a year ago by Indonesia investigators.

How are other markets performing?

Treasury yields were climbing (link)Friday on news of progress on U.S-China trade and investors were focused on next week's Federal Reserve meeting, where another quarter point rate cut is expected. The 10-year Treasury note yield was up 3.7 basis points to 1.803%,

Oil futures drifted into negative territory Friday, but remained on track for weekly gains as concerns over supply appeared to take over the spotlight from longer-term worries over global economic growth and the outlook for crude demand. West Texas Intermediate crude for December on the New York Mercantile Exchange was off 10 cents, or 0.2%, at $56.13 a barrel, but was on track for a 4.4% weekly advance after ending Thursday at a nearly one-month high.

Gold futures closed above a key $1,500 price on Friday (link), but still short of a fresh near-term settlement high as investors positioned for more easing from global central banks, which could add further support for bullion. December gold on Comex gained $0.60, or 0.04%, to settle at $1,505.30 an ounce, according to FactSet data, following a 0.6% gain for the metal on Thursday.

European stocks ended higher on Friday. After closing Thursday at its highest level since Jan. 29, 2018, the Stoxx Europe 600 gained 0.16% to 398.01.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei was up 0.22% after Trade Minister Isshu Sugawara resigned (link)after just a month on the job.

Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.49%, while the Shanghai Composite gained 0.48% and the smaller-cap Shenzhen Composite rose slightly.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

October 25, 2019 14:55 ET (18:55 GMT)
